title: Optimizing environmental surveillance for early detection of zoonotic pathogens via fecal shedding modeling.
abstract: Zoonotic pathogens pose significant global health threats. Despite this burden, establishing cost-effective early warning systems through surface water-based surveillance (SWBS) remains underexplored, particularly in low-resource settings. Here, we address this gap by analyzing fecal shedding patterns of two typical zoonotic pathogens: Chlamydia psittaci and influenza A virus (IAV) in both patients and birds. Using these data, we developed a novel theoretical framework to evaluate the feasibility of SWBS for C. psittaci and IAV in surface water. Our findings first reveal high positivity rates of C. psittaci (8-16 %) and IAV (16-84 %) were detected in cloacal swab samples, with significant variations observed among different bird species. Specifically, the highest detection rates for IAV were found in chickens (84.0 %, 84/100), ducks (70.0 %, 70/100), and geese (66.0 %, 33/50), while C. psittaci showed the highest positivity in pigeons (16 %, 8/50) and chickens (16 %, 16/100).
